text.p: The following are the reports carried by Estonia's newspapers on Monday. Reuters has not verified these reports and does not vouch for their accuracy:
- Estonian peace-keeping company will leave for Norway for training before a mission in Lebanon.
- President Lennart Meri has sent a plan to increase Estonia's security to Washington, which includes a call for a security partnership.
- An Estonian-Finnish visa-free travel agreement will probably be postponed since Finland is presenting more requirements, a foreign ministry official said.
- Estonian investment opportunities are excellent, British Foreign Trade Council chairman Martin Laing said after a visit to Estonia last week.
- Estonia sold its only marine research vessel to Swedish Navy, allegedly below its true value.
- U.S. State Department spokesman Nicholas Burns commented on the re-election of Lennart Meri, described him as a democrat and an inspiring leader.
- The Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) will open its office in Tallin early next year and two agents will be assigned to the U.S. Embassy.
- The fire in the Oru peat fields in northeast Estonia continues for the second week and fire-fighters fear that wind may increase the burning area.
- The inactive chemical plant project Ceosil received 18 million kroon credit from the U.S., which will enable to pay debts and purchase raw material. The firm will produce washing powder.
- Estonia's largest food concern, ETFC, has decided to support the EKSEKO pig farm to prevent its bankruptcy, which could lead to the collapse of meat production in Estonia.
